item.title: Introducing Multi-Agent Workflows in Foundry Agent Service
item.description: Across industries, organizations are moving from experimenting with single agents to running AI at the center of their business operations. While single agents excel at focused tasks, customers quickly discover that real enterprise work stretches across multiple steps, involves different roles, and requires strong governance. To operationalize Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/foundry/introducing-multi-agent-workflows-in-foundry-agent-service

item.title: Visual Studio – Built for the Speed of Modern Development
item.description: The release of Visual Studio 2026 two weeks ago marks the next evolution in Microsoft’s 50-year commitment to deliver the tools that developers love and enterprises trust, built to move at the pace of modern development. Software development is moving faster than ever, and Visual Studio is evolving right along with you. item.title: Why does XAML break down when I have an element that is half a billion pixels tall?
item.description: A customer reported that their program encountered rendering problems when they created elements that were a half billion pixels tall, and they wondered why this was happening. A half billion pixels is an awful lot of pixels. At 96 pixels per inch, that gives you an element whose height is over 82 miles (132 km). There is no monitor Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/oldnewthing/20251124-00/?p=111811

item.title: Announcing the Public Preview of Azure Command Launcher for Java
item.description: Today we are announcing the Public Preview of the Azure Command Launcher for Java, a new tool that helps developers, SREs, and infrastructure teams standardize and automate JVM configuration on Azure. The goal is to simplify tuning practices and reduce resource waste across Java workloads. Sign up for the gated preview here: https://aka.m Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/foundry/foundry-local-comes-to-android

item.title: Is Write­Process­Memory faster than shared memory for transferring data between two processes?
item.description: Say you need to transfer a large amount of data between two processes. One way is to use shared memory. Is that the fastest way to do it? Can you do any better? One argument against shared memory is that the sender will have to copy the data into the shared memory block, and the recipient will have to copy it out, resulting in two e Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/oldnewthing/20251119-00/?p=111800

DiskANN is a cutting-edge algorithm for efficient vector similarity search, making it ideal for powering recommendation systems Link to article: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/azure-sql/public-preview-of-vector-indexing-in-azure-sql-db-azure-sql-mi-and-sql-database-in-microsoft-fabric
